questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the superior orbital fissure?
questions.solution:
The optic nerve (2nd cranial nerve) passes through the optic canal, not the superior orbital fissure.

Anatomy of the orbit

Orbit is a pear-shaped cavity, the stalk of which is the optic canal. The volume of the orbit is 30 cc.

Walls of the orbit Bones forming them
Roof

Lesser wing of the sphenoid

The orbital plate of the frontal bone
Lateral wall (strongest wall)

Greater wing of the sphenoid

Zygomatic bone
Floor (most frequently fractured wall)

Zygomatic bone

Maxillary bone

Palatine bone
Medial wall (thinnest wall)

Maxillary bone

Lacrimal bone

Ethmoid bone

Sphenoid bone


The image below shows the bones forming the orbit.

The inferior orbital fissure lies between the greater wing of the sphenoid and the maxilla, connecting the orbit to the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae. Through it run the maxillary nerve, the zygomatic nerve, and branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion, as well as the inferior ophthalmic vein.

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: You are volunteering in a medical camp held in an orphanage. You see a kid with hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible along with antimongoloid slant of palpebral fissures as shown below. These findings correspond to which of the following syndrome?
questions.solution:
The given findings correspond to Treacher–Collins syndrome.

Treacher–Collins syndrome/Mandibulofacial dysostosis refers to a condition resulting from the hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible.

Ocular features:

  • Indistinct inferior orbital margin
  • Coloboma of the lower eyelid
  • Anti-mongoloid slant of palpebral fissures

Systemic features

  • Macrostomia with a high-arched palate
  • External ear deformity
  • Bird-like face

The image below shows features of Treacher–Collins syndrome.

Craniofacial dysostosis/Crouzon syndrome refers to the premature closure of the coronal and sagittal sutures (brachycephaly—clover-leaf skull) associated with maxillary hypoplasia. Ocular associations include the following:

  • Blue sclera
  • Megalocornea
  • Aniridia
  • Glaucoma
  • Cataract
  • Ectopia lentis
  • Optic nerve hypoplasia

The image below shows a baby with Crouzon syndrome.

Apert syndrome is the most severe form of craniosynostosis, involving premature closure of multiple cranial sutures (acrocephaly), along with syndactyly of the fingers and toes.

The image below shows the hands of a patient with Apert syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with a history of trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario plus the supportive CT image showing the "hanging drop sign" is suggestive of a blowout fracture of the orbital wall.

Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit.

The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common.

Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign".

Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive management with analgesics and antibiotics.

Le fort fracture- Is the term used to describe different types of maxillary fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit. 

Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor.

The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit (Option A).

The fractures of the roof(Option C) are relatively rare and most often do not require any treatment.The lateral wall(Option B) of the orbit is the most solid orbital wall and a fracture here is usually seen in injuries with extensive facial damage.

The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common.

Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign".

Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive management with analgesics and antibiotics.

The below given X-ray image in water's view shows "hanging drop sign".

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the clinical sequelae expected in a patient with orbital blowout fracture is false?

choices.text: Anesthesia of the cheek is very common.
Emphysema of eyelids is more common with medial wall fracture.
Enophthalmos develops about 10 days after the injury.
Severe ocular damage is seen in most cases.

questions.solution:
Severe ocular damage associated with a "blowout" fracture is rare.

This is because a "blowout fracture" is nature’s way of protecting the globe from injury.

Clinical features of blow out fracture are as follows:

  • Periorbital edema
  • Paresthesia and anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of the nose, upper lip, and upper teeth)
  • Emphysema of the eyelids-more frequent with medial wall fractures
  • Proptosis-seen initially due to orbital edema and hemorrhage.
  • After about 10 days, as the edema decreases, the eyeball sinks backward and somewhat inferiorly, resulting in enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis.
  • Double diplopia- diplopia in upward as well as downward gaze

questions.text: Two people who got in a brawl are brought to the emergency department because of severe facial injuries. In one of those patients, there is periorbital ecchymosis and anesthesia over the cheek. Orbital blowout fracture is suspected. What X-ray finding will confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray finding seen in an orbital blowout fracture is hanging drop/tear-drop sign. 

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

The optimal time for surgery following a blowout fracture is 10–14 days.

Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture are as follows:

  • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma
  • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum
  • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in  globe  retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze
  • Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm

questions.text: All of the following are characteristic clinical findings that are associated with a history of blunt trauma to the eye, except:
questions.solution:
Vossius ring, not Soemmering’s, is seen after blunt trauma to the eye

Soemmering’s ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract, also known as "secondary cataract." It is the opacity that persists or develops after extracapsular lens extraction.

Blunt trauma to the eye produces:

  • Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.
  • Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract.
  • Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at foveola.

questions.text: What is the most common site of globe rupture following trauma?
questions.solution:
The superonasal limbus is the most common site of globe rupture.

This occurs due to the contrecoup effect—the lower temporal quadrant is the most exposed to trauma; hence, the effect is seen in the superonasal limbus, which lies on the opposite side.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the following clinical finding seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows bilateral periorbital ecchymoses, which is called the panda sign, and it is seen in bilateral anterior cranial fossa fracture. It is also known as panda eyes/raccoon eyes.

The pooling of blood surrounding the eyes is most commonly associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. This finding is typically not present during the initial evaluation and is delayed by 1 to 3 days. If bilateral, this finding is highly predictive of a basilar skull fracture.

questions.text: Clinical examination patients with which of the following conditions would show Dalen Fuchs Nodules?
questions.solution:
Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis and Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) syndrome.

These are local granulomas due to the proliferation of lymphocytes and epithelioid cells and are located between RPE and Bruch's membrane.

The image below shows Dalen Fuchs nodules.

questions.text: Which of the following views would you advise, so as to visualize the optic foramina?
questions.solution:
The Rhese view in an X-ray scan helps in the visualization of the optic foramina.

The optic foramen/optic canal transmits the optic nerve and ophthalmic artery.

Rhese view: for optic foramen

Other X-ray views of the orbit:

1. Caldwell's view: Occipitofrontal

Structures seen:

  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Greater and lesser wing of the sphenoid
  • Ethmoid and frontal sinus
  • Floor of the sella

2. Water's view:

  • Occipitomeatal: floor of the orbit is seen (important in "blow-out" fractures)
  • Occipitomental: maxillary sinus and floor of the orbit

3. Towne’ s view:

Structures seen

  • Dorsum sellae of the sphenoid bone
  • Inferior orbital fissure

questions.text: Heterochromia iridis may be caused by which of the following intraocular foreign bodies?
questions.solution:
Heterochromia iridis may be caused by iron deposition.

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. In siderosis bulbi, the iris is first stained greenish and later turns reddish brown, causing heterochromia iridis. 

Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye. Clinical features include the following:

  • Kayser–Fleischer ring- a golden brown ring that occurs due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet’s membrane of the cornea.
  • Sunflower cataract- produced by the deposition of copper under the anterior capsule of the lens. It is brilliant golden green in color and arranged like the petals of a sunflower.

The image below shows siderosis bulbi.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to produce this finding on CT?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows hyperostosis of the lateral wall of the left orbit.

Hyperostosis causing lesions are:

  1. Sphenoid wing meningioma
  2. Fibrous dysplasia
  3. Metastasis from cancer prostate

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and decreased vision over his right eye. He gives a history of accidental exposure with a cleaning agent that contains ammonia. Ocular examination finding is given below. According to the Roper-Hall system, what is the grade of chemical injury?
questions.solution:
The image shows a grade II chemical injury. There is limbal ischaemia in the lower left quadrant involving <1/3 of the limbus and a hazy cornea with visible iris details.

The Roper–Hall system is used for the classification of chemical injuries to the eye.

Grade Limbal ischemia Cornea Iris Prognosis
I Absent Clear Visible Excellent
II <1/3 of limbus Hazy Visible Good
III 1/3 - 1/2 of limbus  Hazy Obscured Guarded
IV >1/2 limbus Opaque Obscured Poor

Chemical injuries to the eye:

  • Alkali burns are twice as common as acid burns.
  • Alkalis tend to penetrate more deeply than acids, as the latter coagulate surface proteins, forming a protective barrier.
  • Most commonly involved alkalis are ammonia, sodium hydroxide, and lime.
